text: Uh, the questions is concerning the changes in the roles of American women in the past several generations and you know, in their, the society we live in.

speaker: A
text: What do you think has occurred there?

speaker: B
text: Well, I think one of the major changes is the whole attitude towards women in the work place and the role of women in doing jobs outside of the home.

speaker: B
text: That's probably one of the major changes I see over the last period of time.

speaker: A
text: But are, are they being given the full honor for the work they are doing and for the, uh, oh my gosh, I can't think of the word, but for the, what they have to accept that's they are responsible for.

speaker: A
text: Uh, responsibilities is what I am trying to say.

speaker: B
text: I think it has come a long ways in terms of giving them equal opportunities

speaker: B
text: but I still think in lots of job markets they are not treated as equals.

speaker: B
text: In other words, in some respects the other direction, in some job markets they don't really want to be treated as equals.

speaker: A
text: By the same token, most, in most cases, women have the jobs with the same responsibility of men who have been there before, but at lower salaries.

speaker: B
text: I think that's  generally speaking, pretty true.

speaker: B
text: And I think that's what we really ought to look at that, going is, if they are going to do equal work they ought to get equal pay.

speaker: B
text: And that, uh, they ought to have equal opportunities to advance to those positions

speaker: B
text: and I don't think that we have gotten there yet.

speaker: A
text: Well, what changes do you think are most significant over the past few years?

speaker: A
text: or is it just a general switch over?

speaker: B
text: I think it's generally that switch over.

speaker: B
text: And, and I think that switch over has been more in the work force.

speaker: B
text: I don't think that women are treated as equals in the home as much as they are in the work force.

speaker: B
text: I think those women who are out working are probably still expected to carry more responsibility at home that the husband is having them, on the other side of that coin picked up as much responsibility at home.

speaker: B
text: So they have one and three quarters jobs now. Whereas the husbands have one and a quarter.

speaker: A
text: and this upsets the man because we have always been built to think that we were sort of head of the household.

speaker: A
text: So do you think that is going to be uh, difficult saying as far as marriages and people enjoying each other in the future years?

speaker: B
text: I think also in terms of parenting.

speaker: B
text: I think there is going to be some increasing problem because I think women are expecting husbands to do more parenting

speaker: B
text: and I am not sure they are becoming more skilled at it.

speaker: B
text: So I think it really has put some additional stresses on the family units.

speaker: A
text: Well, do you have any opinion of potential changes that may occur in the next generation, specifically?

speaker: B
text: Well, I, I think one of the things that always happens is I think is when the one end you know were moving out to the end where a lot of women will be at work

speaker: B
text: and then I think we are starting to see now some tendency of women at mid thirties

speaker: B
text: and so the opinion of this career thing isn't all that it is cracked up to be

speaker: B
text: and I want to go back and do something else.

speaker: B
text: I think we will probably see the pendulum in terms of the work force swing back a little bit.

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: People have gotten out and gotten use to incomes coming in.

speaker: A

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: Uh, we have a, a budget,

speaker: B
text: but not as strict now as we used to because we don't have quite such a tight financial situation.

speaker: B
text: So it, it's, uh, it's helpful.

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: and that did get us so that, you know, the house is paid for and, uh, other major things are taken care of

speaker: B
text: and now we can relax a little bit more because basically we don't really require as much on a daily or a monthly basis as we did before,

speaker: B
text: so we don't have to have quite as strict, uh, a budget as we did.

text: but I know that I go to the grocery store that we always stick within, you know, five dollars between here and there.

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B

speaker: B
text: and we freeze a lot of that,

speaker: B

speaker: A
text: Oh, you guys sound pretty self sufficient

speaker: B
text: if anything is absolutely out, make a note of it

text: and then, uh, the next time I go to the store, why, I pick it up and fill it up.

speaker: B
text: So it's, it's worked very well that way.

speaker: B

text: But, I like it all except, uh, really I don't, I don't really care that much for the trout.

speaker: A
text: I think I had rather have a catfish than I would a trout

text: Well, I, I don't blame you.

speaker: A
text: Well, now, what would you say about these everyday invasions of our privacy?

speaker: A
text: What ideas do you have on that, Doug?

speaker: B
text: Um, see, I'm not sure that,

speaker: B
text: I don't think they're necessarily widespread in this country,

speaker: B
text: but I think that the opportunity is definitely there for, um, people to invade your privacy when they want to,

speaker: B
text: Well, it's certainly not that difficult to tap a phone.

speaker: B
text: It's completely trivial to, for instance, listen in on someone's car phone or walk around phone, since they're just radio signals.

speaker: B
text: well, what's the first thing that comes to your mind?

speaker: A
text: Well, the thing that I thought they were, uh, concerned about was, was people calling on the phone from all over the country to sell you something

speaker: A
text: and in reality in many cases, they knew, or they had information about you that was purchased from some other organizations.

speaker: A
text: And I thought was, uh, beginning to invade the privacy of people, because the things about where you live and, and maybe what you purchased in past months is then put down and sent to someone else in the same business,

speaker: A
text: and they in return, come back and try to sell you something with this additional knowledge.

speaker: A
text: To me that's an invasion of privacy.

speaker: B
text: I agree with you there, for sure.

speaker: B
text: Um, and I think that all that information is quite easy for anyone to get.

speaker: B
text: It's possible for almost anyone to get information about your credit history, for instance, if they just, um, twist the right arm or claim to be from the right organization when they're calling the credit company.

speaker: B
text: It's, you know, possible for a thirteen year old hacker with a modem to find out almost anything about your personal history, not to mention, change it if he wants to.

speaker: A
text: You mean your history in regards to, uh the charge card company or something like that?

speaker: B
text: and they'll probably goes into other things, like, you know, your records with the government or utility companies or anything.

speaker: A
text: Do you consider these serious, uh, problems?

speaker: B
text: Um, uh, not, not yet anyways, because I don't think they're widespread enough,

speaker: B
text: but I think they have the potential of becoming serious problems.

speaker: A
text: Well, what should we do about it,

speaker: A
text: or what could be done about it, do you think to correct it?

speaker: B
text: Um I'm not really sure, because the, I mean society is going more and more electronic,

speaker: B
text: and there are certainly benefits to its doing so,

speaker: B
text: and it's hard to, hard to say whether the, um, risks have potential of outweighing the benefits or not,

speaker: B
text: and I'm not sure what can be done to ensure that they don't.

speaker: B
text: do you see any out for us?

speaker: A
text: Well, I would think that, uh, information held on records, uh, by any company or charge card dealer or person should be absolutely private and, and not be allowed to be, uh, to, given out by those companies.

speaker: A
text: I mean, it should be made a, a, uh, national or a state law to protect people so that, uh, you would then feel more free to deal direct with these companies.

speaker: A
text: In other words, if you call the company yourself, directly, uh, and then know that what you tell them will be on their records but will not be available to anyone else, uh, you know, from the outside, so to speak then you would, you would feel more free to, uh, to go into detail with them

speaker: A
text: but, but we have no control of that now

speaker: A
text: and then, uh, you, you're, when you're talking with them you really don't want to tell them everything that's on your mind because you, you feel that it someday might be used against you.

speaker: A

speaker: A

speaker: A
text: you can put out aluminum cans,

speaker: A

text: because I hate to see our landfills being filled up and, uh, growing bigger and bigger and bigger where they are becoming a big problem for not only the people that are living today, but for the future also.

speaker: A
text: to me, all this, uh, space exploration that we've done thus far has told us that there's no other place like earth. That, uh, we can't live on Mars.

speaker: A
text: I mean, this is the, the place that we have to live.

speaker: A
text: I mean, there's, uh, no other resource for us to, to look at other than here.

speaker: A
text: So, it's kind of like, to me,

speaker: A
text: I would like to see a lot more money being put toward taking care of the environment that we have here and not so much emphasis put on what's going out in space

speaker: A

speaker: A
text: the space program has taught us that there is no other place for us.

speaker: A
text: It's it for us, you know what I mean? Uh, unless technology makes the decision that we are all going to live in space or whatever.

speaker: A

speaker: A

speaker: B
text: Well, uh, as far as the practical aspects go, I suspect that the space station may actually be a good compromise between, you know, deep space I'm sorry, deep space exploration and, uh, and not doing anything because we have the opportunity to off load some things to the space station.

speaker: B
text: And, uh, you know, perhaps we can find better techniques for doing things that, uh, we'd normally do down here that are damaging to the environment.

speaker: A

speaker: A

speaker: A
text: It's like, God if I don't get to see the sun I'm going to be in this bad mood all this entire time

speaker: A

speaker: A
text: You know, when is the sun going to come out?

speaker: A
text: So I wonder how, you know, somebody living up in space is going to be able to tolerate never seeing the sun You know, in the aspect that we see it. Uh, and never seeing, uh, you know, light, bright days, you know.

text: and that has to affect you if you are human, you know.

speaker: A
text: So they had to work all that, that anger out, and the, and the nightmares that come along with it.

speaker: A
text: I do not, I do not really think that anybody can ever forget that,

speaker: A
text: but they can, they can reason and, and try to adjust to, to why they were there.

speaker: B
text: Well, you see that is what the veterans are so angry about now.

speaker: B
text: They say, "Well, we're, going to listen to this and we are going to look at this, find out what our mistakes were, and we are not going to make them again."

speaker: B
text: But that does not undo the ones that were done.

speaker: B
text: And that is what makes the veterans angry.

speaker: B
text: I do not know a solution.

speaker: B
text: But I sure cannot blame them for being angry.

speaker: B
text: On the other hand, you know, you can be angry about something for a very long time,

speaker: B

speaker: A
text: And then it just blew up into the war.

text: Well, it has been that way for a very, very long time, though.

text: So, and, and, and the Asians historically have always had these kinds of wars going on.

speaker: B
